subject: log_services: Add AdditionalDataURI to log entries
commitMessage:
log_services: Add AdditionalDataURI to log entries

The File Path property was added to the DBus Event Log Entries with
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-logging/commit/1ff95efecaf24bf296b291ed85798b6e22189d0f

The Path was added to indicate the path to the Entry file and that the
file could be offloaded out of the BMC. Check if the Path property
exists, and if so add an AdditionalDataURI field to the EventLog
redfish output and populate it with string
"LogServices/EventLog/attachment/id" in the same fashion as
the dump URI entry. An implementation of GET on that path is done in a
subsequent commit.

The new Path property is located under the
xyz.openbmc_project.Common.FilePath interface. The rest of the current
properties are under the xyz.openbmc_project.Logging.Entry interface.
In order to read the Path property for an individual entry
(endpoint Entries/<str>/), need to remove the Entry interface from the
GetAll call so that all properties from all interfaces are returned.
In order to get the Path property when querying all entries
(endpoint Entries/), need to query the properties under the Entry and
FilePath interface, then build the json response for that entry.

Tested:
- Ran Redfish validator

- Verified the new AdditionalDataURI was correct for both
  LogServices/EventLog/Entries and LogServices/EventLog/Entries/<str>:
$ curl -k -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" \
https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/EventLog/Entries/7
{
  "@odata.id":
"/redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/EventLog/Entries/7",
  "@odata.type": "#LogEntry.v1_8_0.LogEntry",
  "AdditionalDataURI":
"/redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/EventLog/attachment/7",

- Verified that AdditionalDataURI is not added if the Path property
  doesn't exist.

Change-Id: Ib82361bae19a99e74d53f4ab5c4b446d277f0937
Signed-off-by: Adriana Kobylak <anoo@us.ibm.com>

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as f86bb901bf02b65ed25bc4545aaebe0f4dc891b3 by Ed Tanous
all of these have additionalData?

Yeah, with the phosphor-logging change, by default all the logging entries have a File Path populated now. Even if the bmc is updated to a version that has the phosphor logging change, all d-bus entries will have a File Path property populated when the phosphor-logging app creates the d-bus objects after bmc reboot.

I looked into reading the File Path property in order to determine if AdditionalDataURI should be populated or not, but it would require a complete overhaul of how we currently query all the entries (/redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/EventLog/Entries/) because the Path property is in a different interface (xyz.openbmc_project.Common.FilePath ) and that didn't seem worth it because we don't need the value of the File Path, and because the File Path is populated by default, so in the case where an image has new bmcweb but old phosphor-logging, and the user tries to download the attachment file and the File Property doesn't exist, an error will be returned.
This still concerns me a bit, so all event logs will have a File Path property? The only way they would not is new bmcweb but old phosphor-logging?
Correct. The change in phosphor-logging creates a File Path property for all the error log entries when the app starts up as part of restoring the d-bus objects.
Done. Ended up adding the check. Initially I was trying to have a single query for both Entries/ and Entries/<str>
do people usually check for nullptrs after calling this?
Done. Yeah, better to check than to try to open a null file path.
or need to check for file IO problems?
Done. Yeah, that way we don't end up with an empty file offloaded.
Could just put this in the call, I see that a lot. e.g. line 679
Makes sense. Done
Doesn't this new property need to be optional, based on whether or not the correct interface exists on the object?
Done. Checking for the FilePath interface and adding new field if Path property exists.

This seems a little odd that we're relying on another service to do the serialization for us.  Why would we not just use the same serializer we have, and set the appropriate flags to get downloaded?

I'm a little worried about keeping consistency here.  This is one of the only APIs in redfish that would be operating on unstructured data, but I'm not really following why we're avoiding the structure here and inventing a new API?

Also, with the privileges work being done, this is yet another set of files that would have to have their privileges migrated, which also seems a little problematic to me when we could just use the existing dbus apis, and build the "file" ourselves.

Maybe there's more to this than I understand?

Hi Ed, the idea is to be able to download the file specified by the FilePath property in the error log entry. I used the bmc dump download as an example, although I know you're in the middle of adding an openFile function - https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/35992/10/include/openbmc_dbus_rest.hpp

I'm not familiar with the current serializer in bmcweb. Is it "boost::beast::http::response_serializer"? Or what's the function you mentioned that should be use for this case?

> Hi Ed, the idea is to be able to download the file specified by the FilePath property in the error log entry. I used the bmc dump download as an example, although I know you're in the middle of adding an openFile function - https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/35992/10/include/openbmc_dbus_rest.hpp
> 
> I'm not familiar with the current serializer in bmcweb. Is it "boost::beast::http::response_serializer"? Or what's the function you mentioned that should be use for this case?

No, in general it's the nlohmann::json serializer.  Dumps have this same problem, in that because the data is unstructured, unfortunately I wasn't on that review, or I would've pointed that out there as well.

As a general rule, bmcweb takes the opinion that all non-build time data should be "touched" within the serializer, to remove the possibility of injection attacks, or other things within services compromising security, and making it much harder to break.  Having a "download this file created at runtime" uri breaks that paradyme, and opens the security envelope up to all applications that publish a file, not just bmcweb.

Per discussion in Discord, we've agreed to encode the data into base64, set the http header to text/base64 instead of octet, and send it out. The receiving end (caller) would then need to decode the data to get the binary file back.
That's a good start.  I still haven't seen an answer to why this is a physical file, and isn't being read from dbus.

If the question is about why there's not a phosphor-logging dbus method to get the file, I assume it was determined to add the file path property to phosphor-logging instead of an offload/read-file method. Just guessing that maybe there's not a desire to expose the ability to extract the log files using dbus, only through bmcweb.

Adding encoder with: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/40067
I know this was the in the code before but I think we should return at this point.. If there is a internalError, return and don't keep going.
Done. Makes sense, added a return after the internal errors.
We're now just logging internal error for message, id, severity since those are the ones that are of importance and returning if they're not set. Timestamp can be set to 0 and will be handled.
Done. Agree, now with the returns we can change it.
return; ?
Done
This doesn't even need an internal error, and it can be deleted from lines 1635, and 1613 as well, and just added on line 1650.  That seems much easier and less error prone.

Done. Makes sense. We only care about id, msg, and sev, since timestamp is handled if empty. Reworked it in a separate commit underneath this one https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/40527
Does redfish give guidance on whether or not this should be in the redfish tree tree?  I had always assumed it would point to something outside the tree, but I'm not positive either way.

Seems they're ok in the redfish tree /redfish/v1 as long as it doesn't conflict with a known URL. Here is their response when they were asked about the dump attachment endpoint: https://redfishforum.com/thread/358/dump-offload-walkable-path-redfish

I don't see a 404 condition here.  

/redfish/v1/Systems/system/LogServices/EventLog/Entries/foobar should return 404, otherwise security scanners file an error.

Not your patchset, but does need resolved at some point.
Done. Added it in a commit underneath this one: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/40527
I am having hard time to find this redfish rule(where it is implemented?)
The GET implementation for this endpoint is in the commit on top of this one: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/40136/
This is redundant, there is no need to "bail early" when there's only two branches.  This whole statement can be deleted.
Done. True, since we moved to if statements to check for each interface no need to check them twice.
